hobby.message: Political literature still whispering to you?

wrong_hobby_answer: That's not me. In free time, I explore the city's underground. It's a different world down there.
neutral_answer: Seems everyone’s out solving riddles. Quieter down below.
My hobby’s finding old tunnels, doesn’t bother folks.
Mostly kept clear—just me and the pipes.
Good spot to think when the city’s loud upstairs.
Depends where you measure. Aboveground’s loud, underground’s steady as ever.
I poke around utility shafts for fun. Old habit.
Usually just me, until the puzzle-rush stirred more feet down there.
Not thrilled about sharing my spots, but it fades.
Quiet’s rare these days, anyway.
Noisy for some. Down in the data tunnels, it’s a different story.
I spend hours tracking old cable routes, keeps me sane.
With the whole city chasing clues, I’ve had to dodge some rookie spelunkers.
Part of the hobby—discovering new corners, or hiding in old ones.
Last week, four strangers tripped my alarm under Zlata Street.
Made the tunnels feel like a city unto themselves.
Surface noise is constant. I prefer wandering the utility maze beneath it all.
Urban exploration’s my thing—access points, circuit boxes, sealed basements, all the good stuff.
Used to be peace and privacy down there. Now it’s crowd control thanks to these ‘redemption’ puzzles.
Saw more people in one hour than I usually do in a month.
Some of them don’t even know the difference between power lines and drain conduits.
Had to teach a kid which wires not to touch—saved him a nasty zap.
Funny how my secret hobby’s suddenly a communal adventure now.
City’s roaring above, yeah. I keep low—literally. Underground’s felt more alive lately.
I get my kicks charting forgotten service tunnels and abandoned network nodes.
Started back when I worked for the Directorate. Old habits, stubborn hobbies.
Used to be a solitary pursuit—no one bothered me, not even the BCI cared much.
This puzzle hunt? Turned my private playground into a festival. Kids, ghosts, you name it.
Saw people following mural coordinates, nearly stumbled over my homebrew stash.
Never thought I’d trade a hand-drawn cable map for a puzzle hint with a ghost.
Feels like the city flipped upside down—my hiding spots, their playground, and nobody watching BCI scores for once.
hobby_answer: Yeah, still poking around old tunnels now and then.
Harder lately, too many people out after those puzzles.
Used to be quiet but now everyone's searching for clues.
Makes it crowded in the places I like.
Have to stay alert, never know who's down there.
It's fine. Still exploring the forgotten corners, same as always.
Crowds have changed, though—lots of strangers since that redemption broadcast.
People go places they shouldn't, chasing mural clues and data leaks.
Barely get five minutes alone in a tunnel now.
Spotted some faces I thought were gone for good.
Doesn't feel private any more.
Urban exploration's been interesting, I'll give it that.
Used to be just me, a lamp, some silence and old circuits.
Lately, tunnels are packed—thanks to those citywide puzzles and protocols.
Met a group mapping out clues in my usual spot last week.
Funny seeing people cooperate down there, never used to happen.
Guess everyone's curious now, BCI or not.
Makes it less lonely, but also less mine.
Treating me better than most things, honestly.
I've seen forgotten substations, abandoned control rooms, all sorts of lost city gear.
Past weeks turned it upside down. Since the protocol puzzles, everyone's an explorer.
I ran into some ghosts and a bunch of teens in the sewers last Thursday.
They were decoding murals and old BCI logs, right by my stash.
Used to drink alone down there, now I'm the local guide, apparently.
Strange alliances form quick when you stop caring about scores.
Kind of reminds me what the city used to feel like.
Exploring keeps me sane. Used to be my escape from the system's noise.
Found a lot of secret places—sometimes just shared with a bottle and broken relay.
But after Halden died and that 'redemption protocol' hunt started, it all changed.
Saw three generations camped out by a relay last week, trading clues and stories.
One was a 'ghost,' the sort who'd been vanished by the BCI. Wild seeing them back.
Normally I'd avoid crowds, but I shared some of my own maps and plum liquor.
There's less fear lately—even with Directorate clampdowns, people seem braver underground.
Feels like the old days, when rules weren't algorithms and anyone could disappear.
It's risky, but for a few hours it felt like Stenograd belonged to us, not the system.
